content: It would probably be smart to acquire a dozen diesels with AIP. Then we could build diesels for Taiwan who really needs them against mainland China's growing sub fleet. From strategypage. quote: Virginia's Kid Brother March 10, 2009: The U.S. Navy continues to entertain an internal debate over the issue of just how effective non-nuclear submarines would be in wartime, and whether the U.S. should buy some of these non-nuclear boats itself. This radical proposal is based on two compelling factors. First, the U.S. Navy may not get enough money to maintain a force of 40-50 SSNs (attack subs.) Second, the quietness of modern diesel-electric boats puts nuclear subs at a serious disadvantage, especially in coastal waters. In an attempt to settle the matter, from 2005 to 2007, the United States leased a Swedish sub (Sweden only has five subs in service), and its crew, to help train American anti-submarine forces. This Swedish boat was a "worst case" scenario, an approach that is preferred for training. The Gotland class Swedish subs involved are small (1,500 tons, 200 feet long) and have a small crew of 25. The Gotland was based in San Diego, along with three dozen civilian technicians to help with maintenance. For many years before the Gotland arrived, the U.S. Navy had trained against Australian diesel-electric subs, and often came out second. The Gotland has one advantage over the Australian boats, because of its AIP system (which allows it to stay under water, silently, for several weeks at a time). Thus the Gotland is something of a worst case in terms of what American surface ships and submarines might have to face in a future naval war. None of America's most likely naval opponents (China, North Korea or Iran), have AIP boats yet, but they do have plenty of diesel-electric subs which, in the hands of skilled crews, can be pretty deadly. One solution to the problem would be a new French design, the Andrasta class coastal boats. The Andrastas are 855 ton, 153 foot long subs, with a crew of 19 (plus 8 passengers, usually commandos). The boat can stay underwater for up to five days. Surfaced, it can travel up to 5,400 kilometers, at slow (170 kilometers a day) speed. There are sufficient supplies on board to keep the boat out up to 30 days. Thus the Andrastas can be deployed, slowly, anywhere in the world. Most missions would be more like two weeks, before the boat returned to port, or a sub tender (a support ship carrying fuel, supplies, maintenance capabilities, and even relief crews). The Andrasta has six forward firing torpedo tubes, which can also carry mines or anti-ship missiles. There are no reloads, all the weapons are stored in the torpedo tubes. There is a special chamber for letting divers exit the boat while underwater. These boats cost $200 million, a tenth of the cost of a Virginia class SSN (a 7,700 ton, 377 foot long boat with a crew of 134 and over 30 torpedoes and missiles on board). Based on the experience with Australian and Swedish subs, the U.S. Navy has been developing new anti-submarine tactics and equipment. In secret, obviously. But apparently the modern, quiet diesel electric boats continue to be a major threat to U.S. surface warships and subs. Meanwhile, potential enemies build... (...)

title: USN might buy diesel subs again

content: quote: Originally posted by Canuck_Centaur: [b]the U.S. Navy may not get enough money to maintain a force of 40-50 SSNs (attack subs.) Was there any doubt under our new administration?

title: USN might buy diesel subs again

content: Not a bad move. D/E subs are much cheaper, a lot quieter and easier to maintain. The only drawback is that they don't have as long of a range unless they start doing RAS's with them. But, with our Naval facilities in Bahrain and Yokosuka, there should not be too many problems with coverage of AOR anyway. And, with AIP, that takes snorkeling completely out of the equation. As a Sonar Tech I would much more fear a really good D/E boat to a NUC boat any day of the week. I wonder why they wouldn't just go with the hybrids, though. Best of both worlds and still much cheaper than a NUC.
reply: Not a bad move. D/E subs are much cheaper, a lot quieter and easier to maintain. The only drawback is that they don't have as long of a range unless they start doing RAS's with them. Best of both worlds and still much cheaper than a NUC.
title: USN might buy diesel subs again

content: Initially, I do not buy that our NUC's would be at any disadvantage in any given situation, shallow waters or not. I'll admit that the technology of diesel equipment may be less expensive to build and operate lessoning some of the deficiencies of older diesel boats, but I think a lot would be given up in terms of response time and range. IMHO and as a former (retired) ASW sailor who was in the middle of chasing Soviet Nuc boats, and saw the training received on our own nuc boats that perfected tactics and strategies, my feeling that building fewer nuc's would be better then building several diesel's! Notwithstanding, the fueling costs for a diesel--wow a Hybrid Sub? What's next--a Solar Power sub?
reply: Initially, I do not buy that our NUC's would be at any disadvantage in any given situation, shallow waters or not. Notwithstanding, the fueling costs for a diesel--wow a Hybrid Sub? What's next--a Solar Power sub?
title: USN might buy diesel subs again

The only drawback is that they don't have as long of a range unless they start doing RAS's with them. But, with our Naval facilities in Bahrain and Yokosuka, there should not be too many problems with coverage of AOR anyway. And, with AIP, that takes snorkeling completely out of the equation. As a Sonar Tech I would much more fear a really good D/E boat to a NUC boat any day of the week. I wonder why they wouldn't just go with the hybrids, though. Best of both worlds and still much cheaper than a NUC. Yup, I agree, and it's about time. A D/E boat in capable hands is as deadly (if not more than) as a nuc boat, fortunately when that D/E boat fires up the diesels to recharge it's batteries they're a bit easier to find even in heavy traffic areas. A very cost effective solution if'n your needin a few subs- and if they go down you don't need to worry much about tech proliferation.

content: Compared to a NUKE: How long can a diesel sub stay submerged? How long do the batteries last before replacing? How long can a diesel sub stay submerged? What is the maximum speed of a diesel sub? What is its maximum depth? How much food can a diesel sub carry to last on a maximum-length cruise? Assuming a diesel sub has electrically-generated refrigerated food storage, how would this affect battery output vs a sub with refrigeration? Sames question as above concerning air conditioning. How much is steam used to answer any of the above questions? Do diesel subs even use steam? That's all I can think of. Oh....they would need awfully short vertically launched missles!
reply: Compared to a NUKE: How long can a diesel sub stay submerged? How long do the batteries last before replacing? How long can a diesel sub stay submerged? What is the maximum speed of a diesel sub? What is its maximum depth? How much food can a diesel sub carry to last on a maximum-length cruise? Assuming a diesel sub has electrically-generated refrigerated food storage, how would this affect battery output vs a sub with refrigeration? Sames question as above concerning air conditioning. How much is steam used to answer any of the above questions? Do diesel subs even use steam? That's all I can think of. Oh....they would need awfully short vertically launched missles!

title: USN might buy diesel subs again

content: quote: Originally posted by ACR26: quote: wow a Hybrid Sub? What's next--a Solar Power sub? Natural progression of things I guess. I think the argument will be to paint em pink or green once made Hybrid has nothing to do with what you think. I talked about this a year ago when I finally could due to security issues. Basically, all NUC subs use a nuclear powerplant to heat water into steam. That steam then turns a turbine at very high RPM (8,000+). The Turbine is the prime mover (which is very loud). It goes to reduction gears (which are very loud) to then turn the propeller. The Nuclear-steam plant also provided power through generators (which are moderately loud). Basically, it is hard to make a NUC sub silent. Quiet, yes. But, not super quiet. D/E subs use a diesel engine to charge batteries. These batteries are what are used to run a DC motor that turns the propellers and provide power. When the batteries get low, the diesel engine must be turned on (super freaking loud). But, once the batteries are charged, the sub will run super quiet. D/E subs usually have to snorkel to start up their diesels, but with AIP that is no longer needed. Diesel boats are also slower, but this is mostly to conserve battery life between charges. Hybrids take the best from both platforms. They use a much smaller nuclear-steam plant that is used only to keep the batteries charged at all times. So, they are essentially a NUC/E. On a regular NUC, this plant and everything that comes with this type of propulsion take up 1/3 to 1/2 of the entire boat. That is a lot to maintain, a lot that can break and a lot to try to decouple from the hull. On a Hybrid, the entire plant takes up one space (roughly, 10x10x10). And, it offers all of the pros of both platforms without the cons. Now, this story is suggesting that they are going to buy from either Sweden or Australia. That may be true for the hull. But, I think that they would probably use this new Hybrid technology that the Chinese developed about 10 years ago. And, no Navy sonar shack has gotten a track or even a discrete freq off of one of the new Chinese hybrids yet. And, I do believe one of them is a boomer and the other two are fast attacks. So, not something that gives us much of a warm and fuzzy.
quote: Originally posted by ACR26: quote: wow a Hybrid Sub? What's next--a Solar Power sub? Natural progression of things I guess. I think the argument will be to paint em pink or green once made

Basically, all NUC subs use a nuclear powerplant to heat water into steam. That steam then turns a turbine at very high RPM (8,000+). The Turbine is the prime mover (which is very loud). It goes to reduction gears (which are very loud) to then turn the propeller. The Nuclear-steam plant also provided power through generators (which are moderately loud). Basically, it is hard to make a NUC sub silent. Quiet, yes. But, not super quiet. D/E subs use a diesel engine to charge batteries. These batteries are what are used to run a DC motor that turns the propellers and provide power. When the batteries get low, the diesel engine must be turned on (super freaking loud). But, once the batteries are charged, the sub will run super quiet. D/E subs usually have to snorkel to start up their diesels, but with AIP that is no longer needed. Diesel boats are also slower, but this is mostly to conserve battery life between charges. Hybrids take the best from both platforms. They use a much smaller nuclear-steam plant that is used only to keep the batteries charged at all times. So, they are essentially a NUC/E. On a regular NUC, this plant and everything that comes with this type of propulsion take up 1/3 to 1/2 of the entire boat. That is a lot to maintain, a lot that can break and a lot to try to decouple from the hull. On a Hybrid, the entire plant takes up one space (roughly, 10x10x10). And, it offers all of the pros of both platforms without the cons. Now, this story is suggesting that they are going to buy from either Sweden or Australia. That may be true for the hull. But, I think that they would probably use this new Hybrid technology that the Chinese developed about 10 years ago. And, no Navy sonar shack has gotten a track or even a discrete freq off of one of the new Chinese hybrids yet. And, I do believe one of them is a boomer and the other two are fast attacks. So, not something that gives us much of a warm and fuzzy.
title: USN might buy diesel subs again

content: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: <snipped> Now, this story is suggesting that they are going to buy from either Sweden or Australia. That may be true for the hull. But, I think that they would probably use this new Hybrid technology that the Chinese developed about 10 years ago. And, no Navy sonar shack has gotten a track or even a discrete freq off of one of the new Chinese hybrids yet. And, I do believe one of them is a boomer and the other two are fast attacks. So, not something that gives us much of a warm and fuzzy. Nobody is gonna admit ANYTHING about them Chinese subs, at least not for the next 20 years or so. I'd like to see some more on that hybrid tech you mentioned, but as any turbine no matter what the size is gonna make noise (as well as the geartrain) there's got to some noise thats making it's way through the water.

title: USN might buy diesel subs again

content: quote: Originally posted by MaddogK: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: <snipped> Now, this story is suggesting that they are going to buy from either Sweden or Australia. That may be true for the hull. But, I think that they would probably use this new Hybrid technology that the Chinese developed about 10 years ago. And, no Navy sonar shack has gotten a track or even a discrete freq off of one of the new Chinese hybrids yet. And, I do believe one of them is a boomer and the other two are fast attacks. So, not something that gives us much of a warm and fuzzy. Nobody is gonna admit ANYTHING about them Chinese subs, at least not for the next 20 years or so. I'd like to see some more on that hybrid tech you mentioned, but as any turbine no matter what the size is gonna make noise (as well as the geartrain) there's got to some noise thats making it's way through the water. Well, the Navy has had a few pop up on them while I was in. We never got a track then. So, that leaves 3 classes of boats we never have gotten tonals off of. And, one of those is a D/E that has been around since the early 80s. As for the noise, you must remember that the noise has to couple to the hull, which in turn couples to the water. It is by far much easier to use decoupling methods on a smaller turbine that takes up 1 frame at the center of a boat than one that takes up a few frames over much of the breadth of a boat. That is the main advantage.

I'd like to see some more on that hybrid tech you mentioned, but as any turbine no matter what the size is gonna make noise (as well as the geartrain) there's got to some noise thats making it's way through the water.

And, one of those is a D/E that has been around since the early 80s. As for the noise, you must remember that the noise has to couple to the hull, which in turn couples to the water. It is by far much easier to use decoupling methods on a smaller turbine that takes up 1 frame at the center of a boat than one that takes up a few frames over much of the breadth of a boat. That is the main advantage.

content: Well let me just say it, "DBF!" A deisel is damned silent, unless you can get a track on something that has to stay on, tracking them is hard. Nuke boats are quiet, but compared to a deisel on battery, they stick out like a sore thumb. For coastal work a deisel could be a very good option, also they could be very good for certain types of missions. That being said, I liked my nuke boat, and the various creature comforts it had, even if they were supposedly for the equipment and not the sailors. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

title: USN might buy diesel subs again

content: Most of the time, the only thing I got off of a D/E (if anything) was an AC line. And, it would usually only be for about 30 seconds and extremely faint. Not nearly enough time to get everything you need to evaluate a contact. You get a bearing and that's it. And, you sure as hell aren't going to get a classification. Then poof, it disappears. Nuclear subs you get the whole kit and kabudle. You got AC power, Turbine, Gear mesh rate, water pumps, etc. Sure, they aren't bright lines, but they are there. I can classify most nucs in about 2 minutes or less with that info. And, you have tons of time to get a few legs and evaluated the hell out of the contact.
